turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Morning!

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Erin?  What are you --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You know what, Mr. Potter?  I completely forgot your birthday this year.  And seeing as how you've been so good to me, I think that is a terrible oversight.  So what I been doing over the last few days is I've been putting together a present for you.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Ho - ly - shit.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Oh, now don't get all jealous, Ed.  I got a little something for you, too.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I don't know what to say.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Say you were wrong.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I was wrong.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Say you shortchanged me and you shortchanged yourself.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I did.  Both.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Say you'd be the luckiest son of a bitch on Earth if I didn't up and quit over all this.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: The luckiest son of a bitch in the universe, Erin.  The luckiest son of a bitch in history.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: But I know you're not gonna quit on me.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: How do you know that?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Cause you got a little voice in your head saying, do the right thing.  Give him another chance.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Careful you don't spit from here; you could kill someone.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You see your office?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah.  Yours is nicer.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Oh, okay.  Here it comes.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Here what comes?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: The extortion, the threats ...

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I wasn't gonna --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: "I can always find someplace else to work. Someplace that'll pay me a fortune and give me a view of the French Riviera ..."

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Ed, I swear, I'm not --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Okay, fine.  <u>Fine</u>  You backed me into a corner again.  You're holding me hostage ...

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What is that?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Take it.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Two million dollars?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: The firm took in sixty.  That's three percent.  Seemed like a fair bonus to me.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: When'd they file the demur?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Yesterday.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: How many counts?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Sixty-nine.  We've got good answers to all of 'em.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: Who's the judge?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Corey.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: I've also been thinking about the team. Responsibilities, who should cover what --

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: POTTER
turns.text: I think we should makes some changes.

turns.speaker: EMBRY
turns.text: I was working in the compressor, and out of nowhere the supervisor calls me up to the office and says, we're gonna give you a shredder machine, and send you on down to the warehouse.  We want you to get rid of all the documents stored out there.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Did he say why?

turns.speaker: EMBRY
turns.text: Nope.  And I didn't ask.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Did you get a look at the stuff you destroyed?

turns.speaker: EMBRY
turns.text: Well, it's pretty boring work, shredding -- you gotta find some way to entertain your mind.  So yeah, I took a look.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: And ...?

turns.speaker: EMBRY
turns.text: There was a lot of dull stuff -- vacation schedules, the like.  But then there were a few memos about the holding ponds.  The water in them.  They had readings from test wells, stuff like that.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: And you were told to destroy those?

turns.speaker: EMBRY
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: EMBRY
turns.text: Course as it turns out, I'm not a very good employee.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: EMBRY
turns.text: Well.  There were a few documents that I somehow didn't get around to shredding.  That I kept instead.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: How come you didn't say anything when you found these things?

turns.speaker: EMBRY
turns.text: At the time, I thought, I got six kids, some of 'em want to go to college.  I can't afford to lose my job.  I told myself I was being honorable.  But there's nothing honorable in what I did.  Maybe that's why they picked me for the job. Maybe they knew what kind of man I was.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Oh, hey -- lemme give you a hand there.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Thank you very much.  Aren't you a gentleman?  Mr. ...

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Ross.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Ross.  Real pleased to meet you.  I'm Erin.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Erin.  Cool.  What can I do for you, Erin?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well, believe it or not, I am on the prowl for some water records.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: You come to the right place.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I guess I did.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: You just tell me what you want to look at and I'll be glad to dig 'em out for you.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I wish I knew.  It's for my boss.  He's fighting his water bill, and he wants me to find all manner of bills from all kinds of places.  The easiest thing would probably be if I just squeezed back there with you and poked around myself.  Would that be okay?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Heck, yeah.  Come on back.  Just gonna need you to sign in here --

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Pattee?  That your middle name?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Nope.  Maiden.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: You're married.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Not anymore.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: You know what, Erin?  I got nothing but time here.  Why don't you let me do that for you, and you can get your kids some dinner.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Ross -- you are an absolute angel.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Hey, Ross.  Tell me something.  Does PG&E pay you to cover their ass, or do you just do it out of the kindness of your heart?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: The fuck you don't.  No one calls me Pattee. That heavy-breathing sicko that called the other night could've only found out about me from you.  People are dying, Ross.  You got document after document here, right under your nose, that says why, and you haven't said word one about it.  I wanna know how the hell you sleep at night.

turns.speaker: FRANKEL
turns.text: What kind of chromium is it?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: There's more than one kind?

turns.speaker: FRANKEL
turns.text: Yes.  There's straight-up chromium -- does all kinds of good things for the body. There's chrom 3, which is fairly benign, and then there's chrom 6, hexavalent chromium, which, depending on the amounts, can be very harmful.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Harmful, like -- how?  What would you get?

turns.speaker: FRANKEL
turns.text: With repeated exposure to toxic levels -- God, anything, really -- respiratory disease, liver failure, heart failure, reproductive failure, chronic headaches, bone or organ deterioration -- plus, of course, any type of cancer.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: So that stuff -- it kills people.

turns.speaker: FRANKEL
turns.text: Oh, yeah.  Definitely.  Highly toxic, highly carcinogenic.  Bad, bad stuff.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well, how do I find out what kind of chromium is up in Hinkley?

turns.speaker: FRANKEL
turns.text: Have you been to the water board?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Hunh-uh.  What's that?

turns.speaker: FRANKEL
turns.text: Every county has one.  They keep records of anything water-related within their jurisdiction.  You should be able to find something there.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: County water board.  All righty, thanks.

turns.speaker: FRANKEL
turns.text: Good luck.  Oh -- I wouldn't advertise what you're looking for if I were you ...

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Put your napkins in your laps and eat up.

turns.speaker: KATIE
turns.text: How come you're not eating?

turns.speaker: KATIE
turns.text: Mommy, can I get a flower?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Sweetheart, you can get a whole big bunch.

turns.speaker: KATIE
turns.text: I hate it too.  I hate this trip.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Oh, come on, where's your sense of adventure?  We're going someplace you never been before.

turns.speaker: KATIE
turns.text: I'm gonna hate it.

turns.speaker: KATIE
turns.text: Yeah.  A real moron.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Some kind of half-wit, no-good, big-haired, bimbo, I bet.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Look, I know you're mad.  But the way this job is, things come up at the last minute, real important things, and I gotta deal with them.  Now I don't like me missing dinner any more than you do, but we're all gonna have to get used to it, cause the fact is, it's gonna happen sometimes.

turns.speaker: KATIE
turns.text: It happens all the time.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: That's not true; we had dinner together just last night.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What are you <u>doing</u>?  Where's George?

turns.speaker: KATIE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: George!

turns.speaker: ROSALIND
turns.text: Masry & Vititoe, can I help you?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Hi, Rosalind, this is Erin.  Brockovich. From the file room?  I was wondering if you could tell Mr. Masry that I'm following up on that real estate thing out of the office.

turns.speaker: ROSALIND
turns.text: You've been reading for hours.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm a slow reader, on account of the fact that I look at the word "dog" and see "god".

turns.speaker: ROSALIND
turns.text: Hey, just so long as you see Him.

turns.speaker: ROSALIND
turns.text: Hey, Erin, I thought you were taking a sick day.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: So did I.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What's going on in there?

turns.speaker: ROSALIND
turns.text: Some meeting.  With PG&E people.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: PG& -- Are you sure?

turns.speaker: ROSALIND
turns.text: Yup.  They must be important, too, cause they came on a special plane.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Hey, Ros, where are they?

turns.speaker: ROSALIND
turns.text: In the conference --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Hey, Ros.  Nice view, huh?

turns.speaker: ROSALIND
turns.text: Yeah, I'm gonna start sleeping here.  Masry & Vititoe, can I -- damn it.  Does anyone know anything about these phones?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: There's no way a son of mine hates Funky Town.  It's impossible.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: Well I hate it.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Thank God we got you away from her, huh?

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: Can I play roller hockey?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: We'll see.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: Randy's mom said yes right away.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well, God damn it, Matthew -- Randy's mom doesn't work eighteen-hour days, and Randy's dad didn't leave her, so figuring out who's gonna take who where is a little easier over at Randy's house.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: God damn it, Matthew.  What the hell are you doing out here?

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: I'm gonna go live with George.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: We'll work out the roller hockey thing, okay?  Whatever you want, we'll work it out. I promise.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: You always say that.  Then you go to work and forget you promised.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I never forget, honey.  I try, real hard. It's just, for some reason, I don't seem to be able to organize things right and -- when it comes to you guys, I end up falling short.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: You never fall short for the work people.  I guess maybe you just love them more.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Oh, God, sweetheart, no.  There's nothing on Earth I love more than you.  Nothing.  I promise.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: She's one of the sick people?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah.  She is.  But you know what?  That's why I'm helping her.  So she can get some medicine to make her feel better.

turns.speaker: MATTHEW
turns.text: How come her own mom isn't helping her?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Cause her own mom's real sick, too.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Hey -- those are my files --

turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: Yeah, we had them couriered over.  And listen, good work.  They're a great start. We're just going to have to spend a little time filling in the holes in your research.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Excuse me -- Theresa, was it?  There are no holes in my research.

turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: No offense.  There are just some things we need that you probably didn't know to ask.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Don't talk to me like I'm an idiot, okay?  I may not have a law degree, but I've spent 18 months on this case, and I know more about those plaintiffs than you ever will.

turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: Erin.  You don't even have phone numbers for some of them.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Whose number do you need?

turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: Everyone's.  This is a lawsuit.  We need to be able to contact the plaintiffs.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I said, <u>whose number do you need</u>?

turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: You don't know six hundreds plaintiffs' numbers by heart.

turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: Annabelle Daniels.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Annabelle Daniels.  714-454-9346.

turns.speaker: THERESA
turns.text: Okay, look -- I think we got off on the wrong foot here --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: That's all you got, lady.  Two wrong feet. In fucking ugly shoes.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, hello to you, darlin'.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What the hell do you think you're doing, making all that Goddamn noise?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Just introducing myself to the neighbors.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well, I'm the neighbors.  There, now we're introduced, so you can shut the fuck up.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Ooh, now, see, if I'da known there was a beautiful woman next door, I'da done this different.  Let's start over.  My name's George.  What's yours?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Just think of me as the person next door who likes it quiet, and we'll get along fine.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Now, don't be like that.  Tell you what. How about if I take you out on a date to apologize for my rudeness?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You want my number?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Which number do you want, George?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You got more than one?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Shit, yeah.  I got numbers coming out of my ears.  Like, for instance, ten.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Ten?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Sure.  That's one of my numbers.  It's how many months old my little girl is.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You got a little girl?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah.  Sexy, huh?  And here's another: five. That's how old my other daughter is.  Seven is my son's age.  Two is how many times I been married and divorced.  You getting all this?  16 is the number of dollars in my bank account.  454-3943 is my phone number. And with all the other numbers I gave you, I'm guessing zero is the number of times you're gonna call it.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: C'mon.  I bought 'em for you, to make up for that night.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Return 'em.  Maybe you'll get your money back.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I had a good neighbor, George.  She was 60 and Mexican and she watched my kids for free.  Something tells me you're not gonna be able to measure up to that.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You need help with your kids?  I could probably do that.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm not gonna leave my kids with you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Cause I don't even know you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, and whose fault is that?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah.  I'm probably ruining them.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm never here.  I gotta leave 'em with this weird sitter all afternoon who costs a fortune and smells like chicken fat.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I was serious before, you know.  If you need someone to keep an eye on them -- after school or something -- I don't have a job now, so I'm around in the afternoons.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Great.  Another deadbeat.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm not a deadbeat.  I work when I need to.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah?  And what do you do the rest of the time, live off your trust fund?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I do construction, which pays real good. And I make it last by living cheap.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I hope that's not supposed to impress me.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Are you this hard on everyone who tries to help you?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: It's been a while.  Maybe I'm just out of practice.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Then lemme remind you, the polite thing is to say, thank you, that's a real nice offer, I don't mind taking you up on it.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Why in the hell would you want to watch my kids?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Cause I like kids.  I like hanging out with them.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You're around every afternoon?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yup.  Usually working on my bike.  No big deal.  If it doesn't work out, you can send 'em back to the chicken fat lady.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: This isn't gonna get you laid, you know.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, we'll just see about that, won't we?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What're you doing?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Better safe than sorry.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm gonna put a dead bolt on your front door, too.  This isn't exactly the safest neighborhood in the world, you know.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Thanks for reminding me.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I guess we get what we pay for, huh?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You think it could make you sick, living in a place like this?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Fixing a leak under your sink.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm gonna clean it up.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What kind of person lives like this?  Huh? What kind of person lets her kids run around in a house crawling with bugs the size of housecats?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It's a simple thing.  Everybody gets them. All we gotta do is call an exterminator.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I <u>can't</u> call an exterminator.  I can't afford one.  God, I can't even afford my <u>phone</u>.  I got fired.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What?  But you been working so hard --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Doesn't matter.  Doesn't make one bit of difference.  Oh God, George, how'd this happen to me? How'd I end up so ... so <u>nothing</u>?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You're not nothing, Erin.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well, I'm sure as hell not what I thought I was gonna be.  I was supposed to have one of those great lives, with everything all laid- out and perfect.  I mean, hell -- I was Miss Wichita, for God's sakes.  Did I tell you that?  You live next door to a real live beauty queen.  I still got the tiara.  I kept it cause I thought it meant something.  I thought it meant I was gonna do something great with my life.  I thought it proved I was gonna grow up to be someone.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You are someone.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: No I'm not.  Look at me.  I'm not.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You're someone to me.  You're someone real special to me.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: George, I am just trying to do something nice for my kids on my one day off.  Could you please not give me a hard time about it?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: One toy per kid is doing something nice. Four is ... something else.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Well, hell, I guess that's it, then, huh? They're scarred for life.  They're gonna start holding up 7-11's any day now.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm just saying --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I know what you're saying, and I don't wanna hear it.  I am doing the best I can.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm not gonna quit cause of one creepy phone call, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Come on, Erin.  A job's supposed to pay your bills, not put you in danger.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm not in danger.  I have a dead bolt. Remember?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Look, don't take this the wrong way, but don't you think you might be out of your league here?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: No, see -- that's exactly what those arrogant PG&E fucks want me to think -- that because they got all this money and power, we don't stand a chance in hell against them.  But you know what?  They're wrong.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It doesn't have to be this complicated, Erin.  There's a lot of jobs out there.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: How would you know?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You mind telling me what that's supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: If you got a problem with me taking care of your kids instead of getting some job, just say so.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I didn't say that.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Cause I can get a job.  I will.  And you can start leaving the kids with the chicken fat lady again.  Would that make you happy?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Keep your voice down.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I know what they can sleep through, Erin.  I probably know it better than you.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm so tired I'm about to drive off the road.  Keep me awake, willya?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What do you want, a joke?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: No, no jokes, I gotta pee.  Just tell me about your day.  What went on back there?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Well, come to think of it, we did have a big event around here.  Beth started talking.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What?  Beth?  My Beth?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah.  We were sitting around at lunch and she pointed at a ball and said, "ball."

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm bored, and so are the kids.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Just a few more minutes, then we can go.  Take her, will you?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm just saying -- we have one night to ourselves, why do we have to spend it here?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Cause it's my office party.  If you had an office, I'd go to your party.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: That's Ed.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Lock the door.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: No, I wanna say hi.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It wouldn't kill you to talk about something other than yourself and your own fucking job once in a while --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What do you want to talk about instead? <u>Your</u> day?  That's a fascinating subject.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Fuck you.  Just cause I don't spend all day trying to prove what hot shit I am --

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: That is not what I'm --

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Bull<u>shit</u>, Erin.  Bullshit.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What's going on?  What are you doing?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Thinking.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: About this.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It's a pair of earrings.  I saw 'em in the mall one day, and I thought, damn, those would look good on those beautiful earlobes. So I bought 'em.  And I said to myself, next time Erin says something nice, does something nice, I'll surprise her with 'em.  Know how long ago that was?  Six months.  In six months, you haven't said one nice thing to me.  That's a long time.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I'm just working so hard --

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I know.  But still.  Six months.  I think you oughta either find a different job or a different boyfriend.  Cause there may be men who don't mind being the maid and getting nothing in return, but I'm sure as shit not one of 'em.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I can't leave my job, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, you can.  You could just quit.  People do it all the time.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I can't.  Look -- this job -- it's the best thing that ever happened to me.  I mean it. For the first time in my life, I got people respecting me.  Up in Hinkley, I walk into a room and everyone shuts up just to hear what I got to say.  I never had that.  Ever. Don't ask me to give it up.  I need it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: More than you need me.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I need it.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You already packed up your stuff?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I pretty much knew what your answer was gonna be.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: They said that'd be tomorrow.  They just wanna keep an eye on me another night.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Fine.  I'll drop 'em off tomorrow afternoon.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mm-hm.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Hi.  It's me.  I got a favor to ask you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't do favors for you anymore.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: It's not for me; it's for my kids.  You're the only one I trust them with.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: They up?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Hunh-uh.  Not yet.  Look, don't take any of 'em on your bike, okay?  Call a cab if you wanna go somewhere.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: How long's this whole thing gonna take?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I don't know.  Few days.  Thanks for helping me.  I appreciate it.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: And I miss you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, well -- good help is hard to find.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Think you could learn?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: You know me.  I pick things up real fast.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You shouldn't be driving around, you know. You're sick.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah, but I'm gonna get better.  A lot of these folks aren't.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What time is it?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Real early.  We're just gonna take your car to get some breakfast.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: No, I need my car --

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: We'll just be a minute.  Get a little more sleep.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Promise you'll turn around if you get tired.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I will.  Bye.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm embarrassed.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: That's okay.  I understand.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: It's just -- the pain.  It's only getting worse.  I can't be a good wife.  I can't be a good mother.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm real sorry, Laura.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Know what I always thought I wanted outta life, Erin?  A Jaguar.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Jaguar's a darn pretty car.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I thought if I could spend that kinda money on a car, it'd mean everything else was fine.  I don't even know how much they cost.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: A lot.  But you hang in there, maybe you'll get one.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I mean, it's not a problem or anything, but -- I'm just a little unclear on what those things are.  I thought maybe you'd know.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: What do I look like, Erin?  A library?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Someone stole my stuff.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Nice to see you, Erin.  We've missed you.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I had photos of my kids, plus a mug --

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: -- toothbrush, toothpaste, and a pair of hose.  Here.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: There may be jobs where you can disappear for days at a time, but this isn't one of them.  Here, if you don't do the work, you don't get to stay.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What am I supposed to do, check in every two seconds?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yes.  It's called accountability.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I am not talking to you, bitch.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: <u>Excuse me</u>?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Where's my paycheck?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Have you been logging on?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I moved payroll onto the computer.  It only knows to process paychecks for employees who log on in the morning and off at night.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Now how'm I supposed to do that when I'm not in here most mornings and nights?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You're clever.  I'm sure you'll think of something.

turns.speaker: MANDY
turns.text: Excuse me, are you Erin Brockovich?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Yeah.  Who are you?

turns.speaker: MANDY
turns.text: When Donna told us about you, and what you told her about the chromium, we figured that might have something to do with this, too.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: It sure could, yeah.  Thanks a lot.

turns.speaker: MANDY
turns.text: There's something else, too.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MANDY
turns.text: I know.  It's an awful lot.

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: I'm surprised Donna didn't say anything.

turns.speaker: MANDY
turns.text: You know that thing it says in here about rashes?

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Uh-huh?

turns.speaker: MANDY
turns.text: Well, this old neighbor of mine, Bob Linwood -- he ran the dairy on Community -- seemed like someone in his family always had a rash somewhere or other.  I just figured it was something in the genes.  And you know how it is -- you don't like to ask about things like that ...

turns.speaker: ERIN
turns.text: Hi, sweetie.  Were you a good girl?  Where are Matt and Katie?

turns.speaker: MRS. MORALES
turns.text: Outside with the sprinkler.  So it's good?
